issue.title: Referencing an outer context named subject from a nested context refers to the current subject

repository.name: rspec-expectations
repository.description: Provides a readable API to express expected outcomes of a code example

issue.body:
Please consider the following spec:

``` ruby
require 'rspec'
require 'ostruct'

describe 'an open struct' do
  context 'when instantiated' do
    subject(:an_open_struct) { OpenStruct.new(value: 1) }
    its(:value) { should == 1 }

    context 'when comparing' do
      subject(:another_open_struct) { OpenStruct.new(value: 2) }
      its(:value) { should > an_open_struct.value }
    end
  end
end
```

While with RSpec 2.12.0 it produces 0 failures, with RSpec 2.13.0 it produces the following failure:

```
Failures:

  1) an open struct when instantiated when comparing value 
     Failure/Error: its(:value) { should > an_open_struct.value }
       expected: > 2
            got:   2
```

body: Thanks for reporting this, @AlessandroBerardi.  I've managed to translate your spec into 2 separate failing specs in the rspec-core test suite but I haven't yet figured out a proper fix.
Should `an_open_struct` be accessible at all? Seems like there should be one and only one subject.

In prior versions of rspec, where named subjects were handled by setting a let then setting subject to point to that let the result was that as you nested, that implicit let would remain available. Now that the subject defines first and the let is handled as an alias to subject, as you go deeper, the target of the name changes each time a new subject is defined.

Prior to this version:

``` ruby
subject(:thingy) { 'a thingamabob' }
```

equated to:

``` ruby
let(:thingy) { 'a thingamabob' }
subject { thingy }
```

Now:

``` ruby
subject(:thingy) { 'another metasyntactic variable' }
```

roughly equates to (if subject is available in a let):

``` ruby
subject { 'another metasyntactic variable' }
let(:thingy) { subject }
```

I guess it comes down to whether you see a named subject as an alias for "subject" or as a name for that specific defined subject value regardless of where you are...

With this change, many people will have to return to the older syntax of defined let, then subject that points to the let to avoid the value of a named subject changing as they nest subjects.

For now, that's the fix for my broken tests. I look forward to seeing how this works out. It's the first time I've stumbled across something like this so close to the release!

In my humble opinion accessing `an_open_struct` in the sub context should either throw an exception or refer to the outer context subject, but not be accessible and refer to the current subject, as that is quite confusing, given that the name 'an_open_struct' was assigned to the outer context subject.
@AlessandroBerardi I agree, the current behavior seems wrong.

issue.title: Candidate fix for #800
issue.body:
Fix inner/outer subject confusion when using a named subject.

This fixes #800 while preserving the behavior we settled on in #757.  However, the complexity of supporting `super` in a named subject (look at that crazy metaprogramming I had to do!) makes me think that we should disable `super` in named subjects altogether instead.  @alindeman and I [discussed this previously](https://github.com/rspec/rspec-core/pull/757#issuecomment-11770186) and decided that `super` in a named subject should super to the outer subject, not an outer `let` declaration; however, to prevent the bug reported in #800, we have to make the `let` declaration primary with the subject simply an alias to the `let`...which causes `super` to call the parent `let` method, not the parent subject.

So...I'm thinking of changing this so that it raises a `super() can't be used in a named subject` error instead.  Really, I don't think there's a good use case for supporting it.  It is a bit of a breaking change (since 2.13.0 is out with `super` calling the parent subject), and we need to get a patch release out to fix #800, so that's a bit of a problem, but I'm not sure what to do about it.

body: @nbfritz -- thanks for your comments, it helped me track down this bug. I've got a candidate fix in #804, but I'm not really happy with the level of metaprogramming required to fix this bug and preserve the use of `super()` in a named subject, so the final fix I merge may be a bit different.  Feedback wanted, of course.
